docs.lead_paragraph: WITH no room to expand outward, the 500,000-square-foot White Plains Hospital Center in the densely built center of the city is instead growing within, gutting and redesigning sections of its six-floor building to remain competitive in the swiftly changing health care market. Building upward, while feasible, would be too disruptive, hospital officials say. In the last six months alone, the 305-bed hospital has opened three new centers -- for seizure diagnosis, sleep disorders and colon cancer screening -- at its main location in White Plains, as well as a satellite breast-imaging center in nearby Rye Brook. Less than two years ago it opened a $6.4 million neonatal and maternity center that, among other things, is equipped to handle the needs of vulnerable premature infants.

headline.main: In the Region/Westchester; 'Landlocked' Hospital Expands by Reshaping Itself

docs.abstract: White Plains Hospital Center in densely built center of city is growing within, gutting and redesigning sections of its six-floor building to remain competitive in swiftly changing health care market; photos (In the Region/Westchester)

docs.lead_paragraph: THE man in the black knit cap wanted to break the bad news, but first he had to out-shout the guy on the saxophone. ''We're going to have to find a new place,'' the man in the cap, Alex Saavedra, bellowed glumly to a visitor at Uncle Joe's, a tiny bar nestled among the warehouses downtown here. ''They're turning Wednesdays into House Night.''

headline.main: Hip Yet Prospering. Can Jersey City Do It?

docs.abstract: Article on transformation of Jersey City's downtown neighborhoods from havens for artists, musicians and immigrants to places where young, artsy and educated professionals are moving and opening clubs and stores; question remains whether hipsters and rich can coexist; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: As a third HealthSouth Corporation executive prepares to plead guilty to accounting-related charges, the F.B.I. has expanded its investigation of the company's chief executive, Richard M. Scrushy, to include an examination of his private investments, the authorities say. Mr. Scrushy set up private companies that dealt in airplanes, radio programs and yachts. Some did business with HealthSouth, which did not report the transactions as required by law, a company spokesman said. Investigators also want to determine whether HealthSouth overbilled Medicare, the government health insurance program, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said.

headline.main: HealthSouth Executive to Plead Guilty to Fraud

docs.abstract: Emery Harris, HealthSouth vice president, prepares to plead guilty to accounting-related charges; FBI expands its investigation of company's chief executive, Richard M Scrushy, to include examination of his private investments (M)
